author: Special Correspondent
text:
Hanumakka and Ningappa who donated their son, Nagaraj’s body to harvest his organs.— Photo: By Special Arrangement

The parents of 30-year-old Nagaraj from Magadi, who met with an accident on Tumkuru Road (national highway) on March 25 and was declared brain dead by doctors, saw life in his death.

Ningappa and Hanumakka, daily wage labourers, did not think twice when doctors counselled them about organ donation. Their generous act has now given a new lease of life to six people.

Nagaraj, who worked in a plastics factory on Magadi Road, met with the accident when he was getting back home after work on his motorbike, and sustained severe brain injury.

He was first admitted to Pooja Hospital and then to Lakshmi Hospital on Magadi Road, and subsequently to BGS Global Hospitals in a critical condition.

He did not respond to treatment and was declared brain dead on Sunday. Subsequently, the organ retrieval happened.

Nagaraj’s eyes were donated to Narayana Nethralaya.

The liver was transplanted at BGS Global Hospitals on a 60-year-old man from the city who was battling for life with end-stage liver disease.

His kidneys were transplanted on patients at St. John’s Hospital and Manipal Hospital.

His heart valves were transplanted on a patient at Narayana Hrudalaya.

title: Brain-dead man’s parents saw life in his death
